Title: Europe will buy gas together to beat inflation which has risen to 3.4% - Corriere della Sera
Description: The hypothesis of an alliance between EU countries with the voluntary involvement of national energy transmission operators (TSOs) who distribute the gas. Price growth at the highest since 2008, Italy at 3%.
Original Language: Italian

motivation.title: EU Gas Alliance and Inflation Trends
motivation.introduction: With Europe's decision to collectively purchase gas to tackle soaring inflation, an interesting question arises: How effectively can this strategy curb inflation rates across different EU countries? By examining the inflation trends from 2008 to now, alongside the gas prices and distribution patterns by national energy transmission operators, we could gain insights into the potential impact of this new alliance on each country's economy.

nodes.description: Intensity and frequency of media coverage regarding EU gas market and inflation

structure: Interestingly, the intensity of media coverage about Europe's gas market and inflation is influenced both by how the public perceives inflation and the overall economic stability of EU countries.
The formation of an EU-wide gas purchasing alliance is intricately linked to both global energy prices and the economic health of the EU nations.
Similarly, changes in national energy policies within the EU are also swayed by the same global energy prices and the economic stability of each member country.

How available gas is in European markets isn't just a matter of supply and demand; it's directly shaped by both the formation of the EU gas alliance and the energy policies of individual EU countries.
This availability of gas then plays a crucial role in shaping public perception about inflation trends in EU countries.

What's fascinating is that the public's perception of inflation, which is influenced by the availability of gas, is a key factor in determining whether inflation rates in EU countries actually increase.
It's also important to note that global energy prices and the economic stability of EU countries do not directly affect inflation rates but do so through other interconnected factors.
